instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shorted on board, now 5v cycling and no 20v
threads.message:
Board came in clean looking, no corrosion spotted anywhere so far. It drew about 2,5 amps at ~4 volts and didnt switch to 20V.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS_F</SIGNAL> were shorted to GND

<TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> had an internal short, bridging PPDCIN and PP20VB. replaced it.
<TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR> replaced just in case. pads for both of these looked bad. Pitted, dull grey. Probably from heating up a lot?

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> replaced from identical donor board - no damage found underneath, but did find some weird glue-looking stuff. reflowed <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.

Short is gone, machine now sits at 5.18V with 20 mAmp. [TABLE="border: 0, cellspacing: 0"]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"][B]measurements[/B][/TD]

 		[/TR]

 		[/TR]
[TR]

I'm not (ever) completely sure if my <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> replacement was a sucess. I have no stencil yet and am not looking forward to putting solder balls one by one on one of these again to rule it out. Is there anything else I can check to verify if <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> are working properly?  Anything else to measure with these symptoms?

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>:
[ATTACH]54996._xfImport[/ATTACH][ATTACH]54997._xfImport[/ATTACH][ATTACH]54998._xfImport[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shorted on board, now 5v cycling and no 20v
threads.message:
Compare diode mode readings between both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Better to compare with an working board.
You must be sure chip is correctly sioldered and maybe need to change the other too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shorted on board, now 5v cycling and no 20v
threads.message:
I checked nearly all pins in diode mode (some I couldnt reach a measuring point under a shield by <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> or by J3300) and only this stood out:
pin 62 <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>&3200: 0.951 vs 0.969 on working board
pin 84 <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>: 0.985 vs 0.967 on working board
pin 94 <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>: 0.990 vs 0.968 on working board
pin 95 <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>: 0.987 vs 0.968 on working board

I'm not a heavy diode mode user, but  these differences are very minor and not worth checking out, right?

I still need to check a bunch pins that read 0L on the board im working on to see if those are the same on the working board.

Right now I'm thinking reball <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and put it back again. But I think I'll hold off on that until I get my stencil. This board is my own, so no real hurry.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shorted on board, now 5v cycling and no 20v
threads.message:
Values look good.
Reball <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and report back...
